title: 820-00165 DEAD with Green Light
message:
The board is clean, however PPBUS_G3H have a short to ground.
I inject V on that rail and nothing gets warm.

Can you guys help me on that?

title: 820-00165 DEAD with Green Light
message:
Is already explained on the forum how to inject voltage on PPBUS_G3H.
Do NOT do that again, before measure basics things...

Post exact value you get there.
Then check if any big coil gives the same value.
If yes, check if you get a value close to 000 betwen that coil and PPBUS_G3H.
That means corresponding high-side MOSFET is shorted.
In this way you will never inject overvoltage into CPU.
Thing which you could already done now...

title: 820-00165 DEAD with Green Light
message: Remove F7140 and see if the short is on pin 1 or pin 2. If pin 1, inject away. If pin 2, inspect the board for any of the tantalum capacitors showing goo leaking from them or a crack in any of them.

title: 820-00165 DEAD with Green Light
message: The short is on Pin 2 - PPBUS_G3H

title: 820-00165 DEAD with Green Light
message: Usually the big capacitors aside CPU get shorted, however inject voltaje on pin 2 from F7140 and see what gets hot...

title: 820-00165 DEAD with Green Light
message: I did and nothing gets hot.

title: 820-00165 DEAD with Green Light
message: what is the resistance between pin 2 of F7140 and ground??? How much voltaje and amps are you injecting????

title: 820-00165 DEAD with Green Light
message:
"Post exact value you get there.
Then check if any big coil gives the same value.
If yes, check if you get a value close to 000 betwen that coil and PPBUS_G3H.
That means corresponding high-side MOSFET is shorted."
Why you people always inject voltage on PPBUS_G3H before checking that???

title: 820-00165 DEAD with Green Light
message:
I fixed it! 
Was C7375!

Done
